creator: jergendutch@gmail.com
text:
http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_proxy.html states:
"timeout 0 Balancer timeout in seconds. If set this will be the maximum time to wait for a free worker. Default is not to wait."

However the behaviour is different. We have found that the timeout value here is the time allowed for a reply to be received. Anything that takes longer than this value gets a 502 invalid response from upstream server error.

On all other servers in the chain the request is logged as a 200 status successful error.

Extract from config file:
 <Proxy balancer://name>
 BalancerMember http://cache1.local:80 min=100 retry=60 timeout=30

creator: rpluem@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #0)
> http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_proxy.html states:
> "timeout 0 Balancer timeout in seconds. If set this will be the maximum time to
> wait for a free worker. Default is not to wait."
> 
> However the behaviour is different. We have found that the timeout value here
> is the time allowed for a reply to be received. Anything that takes longer than
> this value gets a 502 invalid response from upstream server error.

The documentation is correct, but you read it wrong.

> 
> On all other servers in the chain the request is logged as a 200 status
> successful error.
> 
> Extract from config file:
>  <Proxy balancer://name>
>  BalancerMember http://cache1.local:80 min=100 retry=60 timeout=30

Here you did *not* use timeout in a balancer context but in a worker context, so it behaves as described by you and as documented in the parameters for the workers a few lines above the timeout documentation for balancers.
To use timeout in the balancer context you need to do the following:

 <Proxy balancer://name>
  BalancerMember http://cache1.local:80 min=100 retry=60
  ProxySet timeout=30
 </proxy>
